markdownRemark.excerpt: This is the second post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first post, we introduce the basic concepts of groups. In this post, we will…
markdownRemark.html:
This is the second post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first post, we introduce the basic concepts of groups. In this post, we will introduce four isomorphism theorems. But first of all, we need to define normal groups.

  • Normal Groups and Quotient Groups
  • Kernel and Image

  • The First Isomorphism Theorem

    • Symmetric Groups and Alternating Groups
  • The Second Isomorphism Theorem
  • The Third Isomorphism Theorem
  • The Lattice Isomorphism Theorem
  • References

Normal Groups and Quotient Groups

Recall that we define the cosets as the following: Given a group G,H⊂GG, H \subset GG,H⊂G is a subgroup, for any g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, gHgHgH a left coset of GGG, and HgHgHg is a right coset. We’ve already shown that all the cosets have the same cardinality (by defining an isomorphism). We’ve also shown that the set of left cosets forms a partition of the group. The idea of quotient groups, denoted as G/HG/HG/H is motivated by the following question: can we define a group based on this set, or can we define a proper binary operation ∘:G/H×G/H→G/H\circ: G/H \times G/H \to G/H∘:G/H×G/H→G/H for this set? A perhaps natural binary operation is g1H∘g2H=(g1g2)Hg_1H \circ g_2H = (g_1 g_2)Hg1​H∘g2​H=(g1​g2​)H. This definition is very convenient, as it has the identity eHeHeH, an inverse for each element as gH∘g−1H=eHgH \circ g^{-1}H = eHgH∘g−1H=eH, and satisfies associativity. But it has one significant problem: it may not be well defined. You may notice that, a coset can be represented in multiple ways as long as g1H=g1′Hg_1H = g_1'Hg1​H=g1′​H. The question is it true that g1H∘g2H=g1′H∘g2H≡g1g2H=g1′g2Hg_1H \circ g_2H = g_1'H \circ g_2H \equiv g_1g_2 H = g_1'g_2Hg1​H∘g2​H=g1′​H∘g2​H≡g1​g2​H=g1′​g2​H? This seems hard to achieve, and indeed this is not true for most subgroups HHH. This is only true if subgroup HHH is normal.

Definition 2.1: Normal Groups

A subgroup HHH of group GGG is a normal subgroup, denoted as H⊴GH \trianglelefteq GH⊴G, if ∀g∈G\forall g \in G∀g∈G, gHg−1=H  ⟺  gH=HggHg^{-1}=H \iff gH=HggHg−1=H⟺gH=Hg, i.e. left & right cosets coincide.

Definition/Lemma 2.2: Quotient Groups

Given a normal subgroup HHH of group GGG, the quotient group, demoted as G/HG/HG/H, is the set of cosets of HHH in GGG, with the binary operation g1H∘g2H=(g1g2)Hg_1H \circ g_2H = (g_1 g_2)Hg1​H∘g2​H=(g1​g2​)H for g1,g2∈Gg_1, g_2 \in Gg1​,g2​∈G.

ProofProofProof. We show that given H⊴GH \trianglelefteq GH⊴G, G/HG/HG/H is indeed a well-defined group. For g1,g1′,g2∈Gg_1, g_1', g_2 \in Gg1​,g1′​,g2​∈G, suppose g1H=g1′Hg_1H = g_1'Hg1​H=g1′​H. First observe that g1g2H=g1′g2H  ⟺  g2−1(g1′)−1g1g2H=H  ⟺  g2−1(g1′)−1g1g2∈Hg_1g_2 H = g_1'g_2H \iff g_2^{-1}(g_1')^{-1}g_1g_2 H = H \iff g_2^{-1}(g_1')^{-1}g_1g_2 \in Hg1​g2​H=g1′​g2​H⟺g2−1​(g1′​)−1g1​g2​H=H⟺g2−1​(g1′​)−1g1​g2​∈H. Since g1H=g1′Hg_1H = g_1'Hg1​H=g1′​H, (g1′)−1g1∈H(g_1')^{-1}g_1 \in H(g1′​)−1g1​∈H. Thus g2−1(g1′)−1g1g2∈g2−1Hg2=g2−1g2H=Hg_2^{-1}(g_1')^{-1}g_1g_2 \in g_2^{-1}Hg_2 = g_2^{-1}g_2H = Hg2−1​(g1′​)−1g1​g2​∈g2−1​Hg2​=g2−1​g2​H=H. The first equality is due to the normality of HHH.

Definition 2.3: Simple Groups

A group GGG is simple it has no proper normal subgroups.

Note that every group GGG has trivial subgroups: {e},G\{e\}, G{e},G. The idea of normal and quotient groups may be intuitive if we make an analogy to integers. If we consider a group GGG as an integer, then its normal subgroup is its divisor, and the quotient group is its quotient (and hence the name). Following this analogy, simple groups are like the prime numbers. Just like studying prime numbers is important in number theory as they are the building blocks of the number system, simple groups are like building blocks or fundamental structures. If a group is not simple, we can always “factor” it out into its normal and quotient groups, just like prime factorization.

Following this idea, we can always “project” a group to its quotient group via a homomorphism.

Definition/Lemma 2.4: Projection Homomorphism

If H⊴GH \trianglelefteq GH⊴G, the mapping π:G→G/H\pi: G \to G/Hπ:G→G/H defined as π(g)=gH\pi(g) = gHπ(g)=gH is a well-defined homomorphism.

ProofProofProof. The mapping is well-defined since the set of cosets is a partition of GGG. It is a homomorphism since g1Hg2H=g1g2Hg_1Hg_2H = g_1g_2Hg1​Hg2​H=g1​g2​H by the normality of HHH. Also note that the homomorphism is subjective.

Kernel and Image

Now we define the kernel and image of a homomorphism.

Definition 2.5: Kernel and Image

Given a homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H,

  1. The kernel of ϕ\phiϕ is Ker(ϕ)={g∈G:ϕ(g)=eH∈H}Ker(\phi) = \{g \in G : \phi(g) = e_H \in H\}Ker(ϕ)={g∈G:ϕ(g)=eH​∈H}.
  2. The image of ϕ\phiϕ is Im(ϕ)={ϕ(g)=g∈G}Im(\phi) = \{\phi(g) = g \in G\}Im(ϕ)={ϕ(g)=g∈G}.

Lemma 2.6: Kernel and Image

  1. The kernel of any homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H is a normal subgroup of GGG.
  2. The image of any homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H is a subgroup of HHH.

ProofProofProof. It’s straightforward to check that the kernel and image are indeed subgroups of GGG and HHH by checking the three axioms or showing that they are closed under multiplication and inverses. Checking that the kernel is a normal subgroup is also straightforward but we will lay out the steps. We want to show that for g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, gKer(ϕ)g−1=Ker(ϕ)gKer(\phi)g^{-1} = Ker(\phi)gKer(ϕ)g−1=Ker(ϕ), or for k∈Ker(ϕ),gkg−1∈Ker(ϕ)k \in Ker(\phi), gkg^{-1} \in Ker(\phi)k∈Ker(ϕ),gkg−1∈Ker(ϕ). We show this by noting that ϕ(gkg−1)=ϕ(g)ϕ(k)ϕ(g−1)=ϕ(g)eHϕ(g−1)=eH\phi(gkg^{-1}) = \phi(g)\phi(k)\phi(g^{-1}) = \phi(g)e_H\phi(g^{-1}) = e_Hϕ(gkg−1)=ϕ(g)ϕ(k)ϕ(g−1)=ϕ(g)eH​ϕ(g−1)=eH​.

Corollary 2.7: Kernel of Homomorphisms from Simple Groups

Given a homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H where GGG is a simple group, then Ker(ϕ)=H or {eH}Ker(\phi) = H \text{ or } \{e_H\}Ker(ϕ)=H or {eH​}, i.e., ϕ\phiϕ is trivial or injective.

The First Isomorphism Theorem

Theorem 2.8: The First Isomorphism Theorem

Given a homomorphism ϕ:G→H\phi: G \to Hϕ:G→H, G/Ker(ϕ)≅Im(ϕ)G/Ker(\phi) \cong Im(\phi)G/Ker(ϕ)≅Im(ϕ).

ProofProofProof. To prove this theorem, all we need to do is to define an isomorphism ψ:G/Ker(ϕ)→Im(ϕ)\psi: G/Ker(\phi) \to Im(\phi)ψ:G/Ker(ϕ)→Im(ϕ). The idea is given the homomorphism ϕ\phiϕ and the induced projection homomorphism defined in Lemma 2.4 π:G→G/Ker(ϕ)\pi: G \to G/Ker(\phi)π:G→G/Ker(ϕ), we define our ψ\psiψ so that ϕ=ψ∘π\phi = \psi \circ \piϕ=ψ∘π, which will complete the proof. The idea is illustrated in Figure 1.

Figure 1. The First Isomorphism Theorem. (Image source: The First Isomorphism Theorem, Intuitively. Nov. 28, 2016. Algebra, Math3ma.)

Formally, let KKK denote Ker(ϕ)Ker(\phi)Ker(ϕ). We define ψ:G/K→Im(ϕ)\psi: G/K \to Im(\phi)ψ:G/K→Im(ϕ) by ψ(gK)=ϕ(g)\psi(gK) = \phi(g)ψ(gK)=ϕ(g). Thus, by definition, ϕ=ψ∘π\phi = \psi \circ \piϕ=ψ∘π, so we only need to prove that this is a well-defined homomorphism. First, ψ\psiψ is well-defined since if g1K=g2Kg_1K = g_2Kg1​K=g2​K, then

g2g1−1∈K  ⟺  ϕ(g2g1−1)=ϕ(g2)ϕ(g1−1)=eH  ⟺  ϕ(g2)=ϕ(g1)g_2g_1^{-1} \in K \iff \phi(g_2g_1^{-1}) = \phi(g_2) \phi(g_1^{-1}) = e_H \iff \phi(g_2) = \phi(g_1)g2​g1−1​∈K⟺ϕ(g2​g1−1​)=ϕ(g2​)ϕ(g1−1​)=eH​⟺ϕ(g2​)=ϕ(g1​).

Second, ψ\psiψ is a homomorphism since

ψ(g1Kg2K)=ψ(g1g2K)=ϕ(g1g2)=ϕ(g1)ϕ(g2)=ψ(g1K)ψ(g2K)\psi(g_1Kg_2K) = \psi(g_1g_2K) = \phi(g_1g_2) = \phi(g_1)\phi(g_2) = \psi(g_1K)\psi(g_2K)ψ(g1​Kg2​K)=ψ(g1​g2​K)=ϕ(g1​g2​)=ϕ(g1​)ϕ(g2​)=ψ(g1​K)ψ(g2​K)

Thus, we proved that ψ\psiψ is an isomorphism.

Symmetric Groups and Alternating Groups

Upon introduction of the first isomorphism theorem, it’s convenient to introduce two kinds of very important groups.

Consider a set S={1,2,3}S = \{1, 2, 3\}S={1,2,3} which contains 3 elements. We can define a bijective map σ:S→S\sigma: S \to Sσ:S→S, which is called a permutation. For example, we can send 1 to 2, 2 to 3, 3 to 1. This permutation is denoted as (1,2,3)(1,2,3)(1,2,3). We can also send 1 to 3 and leave 2 unchanged, and this permutation is denoted as (1,3)(1,3)(1,3). This “parenthesized” notation is called a cycle decomposition. There are in total 3!=63! = 63!=6 permutations. For a set with more elements, the cycle decomposition can be more complex. For example, for a set of 666 elements, a permutation can be (1,3)(4,5,6)(1, 3)(4,5,6)(1,3)(4,5,6). It shouldn’t be too hard to check that a k-cycle has an order kkk. More generally, a (m-cycle)(n-cycle) has an order lcm(m,n)lcm(m,n)lcm(m,n). We call a 2-cycle a transposition. A cycle decomposition can always be written as composition of transpositions, for example, (1,2,3)=(1,3)(1,2)(1,2,3) = (1,3)(1,2)(1,2,3)=(1,3)(1,2). In general, a m-cycle (a1,⋯ ,an)(a_1, \cdots, a_n)(a1​,⋯,an​) is (a1,am)(a1,am−1)⋯(a1,a2)(a_1, a_m)(a_1, a_{m-1})\cdots(a_1, a_2)(a1​,am​)(a1​,am−1​)⋯(a1​,a2​).

Symmetric Groups of nnn elements SnS_nSn​ contains all the permutations permutations on a set of nnn elements.

Definition 2.9: Symmetric Groups SnS_nSn​

The symmetric group on n letters, SnS_nSn​, is a group with n!n!n! elements, where the binary operation is the composition of maps.

It should be straightforward to check that this is indeed a group. It is closed by multiplication and inverse since by definition it contains all the permutations.

Definition/Lemma 2.10: Alternating Groups AnA_nAn​

The alternating group on n letters, AnA_nAn​, is a subgroup of SnS_nSn​, where An={σ∈Sn:σ is a product of even number of transpositions}A_n = \{\sigma \in S_n : \sigma \text{ is a product of even number of transpositions}\}An​={σ∈Sn​:σ is a product of even number of transpositions}.

ProofProofProof. To justify that AnA_nAn​ is indeed a subgroup of SnS_nSn​, first note that the definition is unambiguous. If two products of transpositions are the same permutation, their length must have the same parity. We can first prove that the identity can only be written as the product of an even number of transpositions by induction on the length of the transpositions. This implies that two equivalent products of transpositions must have the same parity. Secondly, permutations that are products of even number of transpositions are closed under multiplication and inverses.

It may be intuitive that the size of AnA_nAn​ is always ∣Sn∣/2|S_n|/2∣Sn​∣/2. However, this can be hard to prove if we don’t use techniques from group theory. By applying the first isomorphism theorem, we can prove this rather easily. To do this, we need to define another type of groups CnC_nCn​.

Definition 2.11: Cyclic Groups CnC_nCn​

For n∈Z≥1,Cn⊂Cn \in \mathbb Z_{\geq 1}, C_n \subset \mathbb Cn∈Z≥1​,Cn​⊂C, denotes the set of nth roots of unity, i.e., Cn={z∈C:zn=1}C_n = \{z \in \mathbb C : z^n = 1\}Cn​={z∈C:zn=1}. The cyclic groups is defined as (Cn,×)(C_n, \times)(Cn​,×), where the binary operation ×\times× is the usual multplication for numbers.

You may wonder why CnC_nCn​ have the same name as the property “cyclic”. Recall that all the cyclic groups of the same order are isomorphic, e.g., Z/Zn≅Cn\mathbb Z/\mathbb Z_n \cong C_nZ/Zn​≅Cn​, so in fact there are only one type of cyclic groups up to isomorphism. We just choose to use one of them for convenience.

Theorem 2.12: [Sn:An]=2[S_n : A_n] = 2[Sn​:An​]=2

ProofProofProof. To prove this claim, we want to define the subjective homomorphism ϕ:Sn→C2\phi: S_n \to C_2ϕ:Sn​→C2​ such that An=Ker(ϕ)A_n = Ker(\phi)An​=Ker(ϕ), and then the first isomorphism theorem gives the claim. Recall that C2={1,−1}.First,wedefineamappingC_2 = \{1,-1\}. First, we define a mappingC2​={1,−1}.First,wedefineamappingA:Sn→GL(n,Z)A: S_n \to GL(n, \mathbb Z)A:Sn​→GL(n,Z)...GL(n,Z)GL(n,\mathbb Z)GL(n,Z)isafieldwhichwehaven’tintroduced,butfornowjustunderstanditasais a field which we haven’t introduced, but for now just understand it as aisafieldwhichwehaven’tintroduced,butfornowjustunderstanditasan×nn\times nn×nmatrixoverintegers.Wesketchthedefinitionmatrix over integers. We sketch the definitionmatrixoverintegers.WesketchthedefinitionAAAwithanexamplewithwith an example withwithanexamplewithn=3n=3n=3.For. For.Forσ=(1,2,3)\sigma = (1,2,3)σ=(1,2,3)$,

A(σ)=(010001100)A(\sigma)= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}A(σ)=⎝⎛​001​100​010​⎠⎞​

We define ϕ:Sn→C2\phi: S_n \to C_2ϕ:Sn​→C2​ as ϕ=det∘A\phi = det \circ Aϕ=det∘A. Without a proof, we claim that this is indeed a subjective homomorphism.

Proposition 2.13: Any subgroup of index 2 is normal.

Given a subgroup H⊂GH \subset GH⊂G where [G:H]=2[G:H]=2[G:H]=2, there are only two left cosets: H,G−HH, G-HH,G−H. For a g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, if gH=HgH = HgH=H, then Hg=HHg = HHg=H and gH=HggH=HggH=Hg; else if gH=G−HgH = G-HgH=G−H, then Hg=G−HHg = G-HHg=G−H since HHH is closed and gH=HggH=HggH=Hg.

Corollary 2.14: An⊴SnA_n \trianglelefteq S_nAn​⊴Sn​

The Second Isomorphism Theorem

Before introducing the second isomorphism theorem, we need some preparations.

Definition 2.15: Normalizer

Given a group GGG, a subset H⊆GH \subseteq GH⊆G, the normalizer of HHH in GGG, denoted as NG(H)N_G(H)NG​(H), is NG(H)={g∈G:gHg−1=H}N_G(H) = \{g\in G : gHg^{-1} = H\}NG​(H)={g∈G:gHg−1=H}.

We claim that NG(H)N_G(H)NG​(H) is a subgroup of GGG, which should be easy to check by applying definitions. Note that HHH is a normal subgroup of NG(H)N_G(H)NG​(H). In fact, the definition of NG(H)N_G(H)NG​(H) can be phrased as the largest subgroup of GGG in which HHH is normal. Note also that a group KKK is normal to GGG iff NG(K)=GN_G(K) = GNG​(K)=G.

Lemma 2.16: Product of Two Subgroups

Given two subgroups H,K⊂GH, K \subset GH,K⊂G, we define HK={hk:h∈H,k∈K}HK = \{hk : h\in H, k\in K\}HK={hk:h∈H,k∈K}.

  1. H∩KH\cap KH∩K is a subgroup of G,H,KG, H, KG,H,K;
  2. ∣HK∣=∣H∣∣K∣∣H∩K∣|HK| = \frac{|H||K|}{|H\cap K|}∣HK∣=∣H∩K∣∣H∣∣K∣​;
  3. HKHKHK is a subgroup of GGG iff HK=KHHK=KHHK=KH;
  4. If H⊂NG(K)H \subset N_G(K)H⊂NG​(K), then HK=KHHK=KHHK=KH.

ProofProofProof. The first claim can be shown by checking the definitions. The second claim can be proven by the following steps. First, ∣HK∣=∣∪h∈H{hK}∣=∣K∣∣{hK:h∈H}∣|HK| = |\cup_{h\in H}\{hK\}| = |K||\{hK : h \in H\}|∣HK∣=∣∪h∈H​{hK}∣=∣K∣∣{hK:h∈H}∣. Second, for h1,h2∈Hh_1, h_2 \in Hh1​,h2​∈H,

h1K=h2K  ⟺  h2−1h1∈K  ⟺  h2−1h1∈H∩K  ⟺  h1(H∩K)=h2(H∩K)h_1K = h_2K \iff h_2^{-1}h_1 \in K \iff h_2^{-1}h_1 \in H \cap K \iff h_1 (H \cap K) = h_2 (H \cap K)h1​K=h2​K⟺h2−1​h1​∈K⟺h2−1​h1​∈H∩K⟺h1​(H∩K)=h2​(H∩K)

so ∣{hK:h∈H}∣=∣{h(H∩K):h∈H}∣|\{hK : h \in H\}| = |\{h(H \cap K) : h \in H\}|∣{hK:h∈H}∣=∣{h(H∩K):h∈H}∣. Third, using the same arguments in the proof of Lagrange’s theorem ∣{h(H∩K):h∈H}∣=∣H∣∣H∩K∣|\{h(H \cap K) : h \in H\}| = \frac{|H|}{|H\cap K|}∣{h(H∩K):h∈H}∣=∣H∩K∣∣H∣​.

The third claim can be shown by working from both directions, and use/check the axioms of groups. For the fourth claim, for all h∈Hh\in Hh∈H, hKh−1=K  ⟺  hK=KhhKh^{-1} = K \iff hK = KhhKh−1=K⟺hK=Kh. Then HK=∪h∈HhK=∪h∈HKh=KHHK = \cup_{h\in H} hK = \cup_{h\in H} Kh = KHHK=∪h∈H​hK=∪h∈H​Kh=KH.

Theorem 2.17: The Second Isomorphism Theorem

Given two subgroups H,K⊂G,H⊂NG(K)H, K \subset G, H \subset N_G(K)H,K⊂G,H⊂NG​(K), then

  1. HKHKHK is a subgroup of GGG;
  2. K⊴HKK \trianglelefteq HKK⊴HK;
  3. H∩K⊴HH \cap K \trianglelefteq HH∩K⊴H;
  4. HK/K≅H/(H∩K)HK/K \cong H/(H \cap K)HK/K≅H/(H∩K).

Figure 2. illustrated the theorem.

Figure 2. The Second Isomorphism Theorem. (Image source: p Groups. Intuition about the second isomorphism theorem. Apr. 12, 2016. Stackexchange.)

ProofProofProof. For the first claim, we’ve already proven it in Lemma 2.16. For the second claim, note that H⊂NG(K)  ⟹  K⊴HKH \subset N_G(K) \implies K \trianglelefteq HKH⊂NG​(K)⟹K⊴HK. For the third claim, we’ve already in Lemma 2.16 that H∩K⊴HH \cap K \trianglelefteq HH∩K⊴H, so H⊂NG(K)  ⟹  H∩K⊴HH \subset N_G(K) \implies H \cap K \trianglelefteq HH⊂NG​(K)⟹H∩K⊴H. The first three claims make sure that the fourth claim is well-defined. To prove the fourth claim, we define the homomorphism ϕ:H→HK/K\phi: H \to HK/Kϕ:H→HK/K by ϕ(h)=hK\phi(h) = hKϕ(h)=hK. To complete the proof, check directly that ϕ\phiϕ is a well-defined homomorphism, ϕ\phiϕ is surjective, and that Ker(ϕ)=H∩KKer(\phi) = H \cap KKer(ϕ)=H∩K; then use the first isomorphism theorem to finish the proof.

The Third Isomorphism Theorem

Given two normal subgroups H,K⊂G,H⊂GH, K \subset G, H \subset GH,K⊂G,H⊂G, then

  1. K/H⊴G/HK/H \trianglelefteq G/HK/H⊴G/H;
  2. Denote G/HG/HG/H as G‾\overline GG, and K/HK/HK/H as H‾\overline HH, G‾/K‾≅G/K\overline G/ \overline K \cong G/KG/K≅G/K.

ProofProofProof. The second claim is a bit like canceling out factors when we are working with numbers. To prove the first claim, we directly apply the definition of normality and check. To prove the second claim, we again define a subjective homomorphism and utilize the first isomorphism theorem. We define the homomorphism ϕ:G/H→G/K\phi: G/H \to G/Kϕ:G/H→G/K by ϕ(gH)=gK\phi(gH) = gKϕ(gH)=gK. Again, we need to check that 1) ϕ\phiϕ is well-defined; 2) ϕ\phiϕ is a homomorphism; 3) ϕ\phiϕ is subjective; and 4) Ker(ϕ)={gH:ϕ(gH)=K}={gH:gK=K}{gH:g∈K}=K/HKer(\phi) = \{gH:\phi(gH)=K\} = \{gH:gK=K\} \{gH:g \in K\} = K/HKer(ϕ)={gH:ϕ(gH)=K}={gH:gK=K}{gH:g∈K}=K/H. The first three items can be shown by checking the definitions and applying the premises.

The Lattice Isomorphism Theorem

Given a normal subgroup N⊴GN \trianglelefteq GN⊴G, there exists a bijection from the set of subgroups of G that contains NNN to the set of subgroups A‾=A/N\overline A = A/NA=A/N of G/NG/NG/N. Specifically, for all subgroups A,B⊆GA, B \subseteq GA,B⊆G such that N⊆A,N⊆BN \subseteq A, N \subseteq BN⊆A,N⊆B,

  1. A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B iff A‾⊆B‾\overline A \subseteq \overline BA⊆B;
  2. If A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B, then [B:A]=[B‾:A‾][B:A] = [\overline B: \overline A][B:A]=[B:A];
  3. (A∩B)‾\overline{(A \cap B)}(A∩B)​ = A‾∩B‾\overline A \cap \overline BA∩B;
  4. A⊴BA \trianglelefteq BA⊴B iff A‾⊴B‾\overline A \trianglelefteq \overline BA⊴B;

The bijection is given by some π:G→G‾\pi : G \to \overline Gπ:G→G, π−1(A‾)={a∈A:π(a)=aN∈A‾}\pi^{-1}(\overline A) = \{a\in A : \pi(a) = aN \in \overline A\}π−1(A)={a∈A:π(a)=aN∈A}, i.e. the inverse is the pre-image of π\piπ.

This theorem is called the lattice isomorphism theorem, since it allows us to “factor” a group into its subgroups, which is the lattice of the group, as the lattice of D16D_{16}D16​ (dihedral groups which we haven’t defined yet) is illustrated in Figure 4.

Example 2.1: Dihedral groups D2nD_{2n}D2n​

Figure 3. The Generators of Dihedral groups D2nD_{2n}D2n​

Dihedral groups D2nD_{2n}D2n​ are subgroups of SnS_nSn​ which consist of the rigid motions (reflections and rotations) of a regular n-sided polygon or n-gon. It should take some pondering, but there are exactly 2n2n2n unique motions, further every motion can be generated by the reflection and the 2π/n2\pi/n2π/n rotation. Say the reflection is sss and the rotations is rrr, then formally,

D2n=⟨r,s∣r2n=s2=e,rsr=s⟩D_{2n} = \langle r, s \mid r^{2n} = s^2 = e, rsr = s \rangleD2n​=⟨r,s∣r2n=s2=e,rsr=s⟩

Figure 4. The Lattice of D16D_{16}D16​.

References

[1] Siegel, Kyler. MATH GU4041 Introduction to Modern Algebra I. Department of Mathematics, Columbia University. 2019.

[2] Dummit, David and Foote, Richard. Abstract Algebra. Third Edition. John Wiley and Sons, Inc. 2004.

frontmatter.title: Abstract Algebra 02 - The Isomorphism Theorems
frontmatter.description: This is the second post of the Introduction to Abstract Algebra series. In the first post, we introduce the basic concepts of groups. In this post, we will introduce four isomorphism theorems. But first of all, we need to define normal groups.

frontmatter.title: Abstract Algebra 01 - The Introduction of Groups
